description:
Letharia lupina, commonly known as the wolf lichen, is a species of foliose lichen found in western North America. It belongs to the family Parmeliaceae and is known for its distinctive appearance and unique ecological role.

Letharia lupina is a yellowish-green to brownish-green lichen that grows in tufted or mat-like forms on the bark of trees, rocks, and soil. The thallus, or body of the lichen, is composed of thin, branching lobes that can reach up to several centimeters in length. The upper surface of the thallus is often wrinkled or uneven, while the lower surface is typically smooth and lacks visible structures.

One of the defining characteristics of L. lupina is the presence of usnic acid, a secondary metabolite that gives the lichen its distinctive color and provides protection against ultraviolet radiation and herbivores. This compound also contributes to the lichen's antimicrobial and antioxidant properties.

As a symbiotic organism, L. lupina is composed of a fungus (the mycobiont) and a photosynthetic partner, usually a green alga (the photobiont). The fungal component provides the structure and protection, while the photobiont supplies the lichen with nutrients through photosynthesis.

Letharia lupina is an important component of many high-elevation and subalpine ecosystems in western North America, where it serves as a food source for various animals, including small mammals and insects. The lichen also plays a role in nutrient cycling and the overall health of the forest communities in which it is found.
